Jeff, you're right, I hope we can get back to it because it's a great
educa=
tional tool.  There are also good visualizations you can do with
4D CPPNs s=
uch as in HyperNEAT: you can look at 2D cross-sections of
the 4D Hypercube =
as pictures on the screen, which gives you a sense of
the (pseudo) infinite=
-resolution pattern underlying the node sampling
density.

The paper I'm ab=
out to announce here has some pictures of such
cross-sections.

ken

--- In=
 neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken-
> 
> That=
 is cool. I am not surprised you learned a lot with that tool. I
think
> it=
 would greatly facilitate an understanding how CPPNs accomplish
certain
> t=
hings. I also think it would help in talks to show the audience how the
> c=
omplexity, symmetry, repetition, etc. arises. In effect, this is the
> embr=
yogenesis of CPPNs shown in slow motion...or experimental
embryology, if
> =
you like, since you could also see the effects of changing the CPPN
> manua=
lly.  
> 
> Please do let us know if you ever get it back up and running!
>=
 
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State Univ=
ersity

> > 
> > We actually did at one time create an internal app that lets you =
do
> > this with Picbreeder images.  We could click on a node in a CPPN and=

> > see the pattern generated at that internal node (which is like an
> > =
intermediate stage of development).  It's very enlightening.  One
> > thing=
 it taught me is that a lot of the shapes are created through
> > additions=
 and subtractions, in addition to compositions.  But those
> > additions an=
d subtractions are very important.
> > 
> > Unfortunately that app has not =
been further developed at this time and
> > is no longer compatible with Pi=
cbreeder.  Perhaps we will get back to
> > it so that it can be made availa=
ble at some point.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff =
Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >>> So I'm thinking that the benchmark resul=
t is less important than the
> >>> comprehension of how the encoding built =
its results.  CPPNs have the
> >>> nice property that they are fairly strai=
ghtforward.  You can look at
> >>> each hidden node and look at the interme=
diate structure that it
> >>> produces.  In e.g. a GRN-based system, on the=
 other hand, it's
> >>> significantly more opaque and difficult to explain,=
 and
therefore more
> >>> difficult to bias.
> >> 
> >> Have you done this =
Ken? Was it helpful to understand what was
going on?
> >> 
> >> Do you guys=
 have a tool that makes this easy to do? I think it would
> > be very
> >> =
instructive to be able to look at the contribution of hidden
nodes and
> >>=
 subgraphs of the CPPN network.
> >> 
> >> jeff
> >>
